channel.title: Raleigh NC Parks and Recreation News
channel.description: Latest news from Raleigh Parks and Recreation

item.title: Screen Writing Workshop (Jan 22, 2026)
item.description:
Join our six-week Screenwriting Workshop and learn how to craft a compelling three-act screenplay from start to finish. The workshop runs from Feb. 25 through April 1, meeting on Wednesdays from 5:30 to 6:30 p.m.



In this interactive and supportive environment, participants will learn the fundamentals of screenwriting, develop their own three-act screenplay, and give and receive constructive feedback on their writing. Writers of all experience levels are welcome, from beginners to those looking to strengthen their skills. This is a great opportunity to grow creatively, connect with other writers, and bring your story to life. Please bring a laptop, tablet, or phone.



Location: John P. "Top" Greene African American Cultural Center
Dates: Wednesdays, Feb. 25 - April 1
Time: 5:30 - 6:30 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Celebrate Black History Month: Things to See and Do (Jan 22, 2026)
item.description:
Saturday, Feb. 7
11 a.m. - 2 p.m.
Age: All
Cost: Free
John Chavis Memorial Park, 505 Martin Luther King Jr Blvd, Raleigh, NC 27601
This celebration offers a variety of activities aimed at educating, inspiring, and bringing people together. There will be food trucks, lessons for littles, Black-Owned Business Vendors, bounce houses, arts and crafts, and much more!



Sunday, Feb. 8
3 - 5 p.m.
Age: All
Cost: Free
John P. "Top" Green Community Center, 401 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd, Raleigh, NC 27601
An unforgettable evening as we honor the living legends of Raleigh, North Carolina—visionaries, trailblazers, and community champions whose work has shaped the cultural, social, and economic landscape of the Black community.



Friday, Feb. 20
5 - 7 p.m.
Age: All
Cost: Free
City of Raleigh Museum, 220 Fayetteville Street, Raleigh, NC 27601
Superheroes come in all hues and have incredible abilities! Learn the history of African American comic book superheroes from then and now. Join us for a discussion and a display of historic comic books, as well as discuss Black superheroes in comics and film.



Saturday, Feb. 21, and Sunday, Feb. 22
1 p.m. and 2:30 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: $15
Mordecai Historic Park, 1 Mimosa St., Raleigh, NC 27604
Join the Historic Raleigh Trolley for this special edition of our popular Black history tour highlighting Oberlin Village. Tours will begin at Mordecai Historic Park and travel to Oberlin, where passengers will disembark for a tour of the Historic Turner House and Oberlin Cemetery and learn about the neighborhood’s history of community and freedom.



Make sure to check back throughout the month as more events will be added.



The City owns parks, a cemetery, and other landmarks with significance to the African American community. Below are a few who have made it onto the local, state, and national registers of historic places.



505 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. Raleigh, NC 27601
Under the federal Works Progress Administration (WPA), Chavis Park was created in 1937 to give black families access to similar recreational opportunities as white families. It attracted black families throughout North Carolina from the late 1930s to the late 1940s. The carousel was installed as one of the main attractions and is one of the few vintage carousels that remain in operation today. The park is named for John Chavis, a black Revolutionary War soldier, who went on to establish a school in Raleigh, where he taught white students by day and black students by night. He also became a Presbyterian minister in 1799. Read more about Chavis Park’s history .



401 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd, Raleigh, NC 27601
The center is named after Mr. John P. “Top” Greene, a community activist and South Park community resident. The center features historical exhibits and displays that interpret the history and culture of the South Park and East Raleigh neighborhoods.



1001 Parker Street, Raleigh, NC  27607
Rev. Morgan London Latta, a freed enslaved person and teacher, founded Latta University in 1892. At its peak, Latta was home to 26 buildings home and 1,400 students, including orphaned children of former enslaved people. The university operated for 30 years. The Latta residence was the only remaining structure on the site, but it was destroyed in a fire in 2007. Read more about Latta House's history. 



120 Prospect Avenue, Raleigh, NC 27603
Mt. Hope, which was established in 1872, is one of the first municipal cemeteries for African Americans in North Carolina. Most sizeable towns in the state opened suburban cemeteries for whites in the post-Civil War era, but very few established municipal cemeteries for freed enslaved people. Several prominent residents are buried there including Rev. G.A. Mial, former enslaved person and educator Lucille M. Hunter, James E. Hamlin owner of Hamlin Drugstore, and Dr. Manassa T. Pope, the first black mayoral candidate in Raleigh. Read more about Mt. Hope's history . 



514 Method Road, Raleigh, NC 27607
The Pioneers Building was the old Agricultural Building of the Berry O’Kelly High School, the first fully accredited and largest rural high school in the state of North Carolina for African Americans. Read more about the Pioneers Building.



511 South Wilmington Street, Raleigh, NC 27601
As the only African American house museum in the state of North Carolina, the Pope House offers a glimpse into the life of one of Raleigh’s most intriguing citizens, Dr. Manassa Thomas Pope, who was the only African-American man to run for mayor of a southern capital during the Jim Crow Era. Read more about Pope House's history .

item.title: Stop by Our Job Fair and Find Your Dream Job with Raleigh Parks! (Jan 22, 2026)
item.description:
Our department has open, part-time positions relevant to all fields of study, career goals, and interests.



Join us at our job fair to chat with leaders from across the department, submit employment interest forms on-site that go directly to our department's top hiring managers, and enjoy free food and fun throughout!



Those who submit an employment interest form at the job fair will also be entered to win an exclusive prize, to be announced soon!



Location: John Chavis Memorial Park

Time: 5 - 7 p.m. 
Ages: 16 +

item.title: Raleigh Parks Restores More Than 90 Acres by Expanding Invasive Species Management (Jan 14, 2026)
item.description:
In 2024, the Invasive Species Program received $500,000 to launch a Master Services Agreement (MSA). This funding allows the City to hire expert contractors to help remove invasive plants across Raleigh’s parks and greenways. 



This new support has greatly increased our ability to care for natural spaces, improve safety, and make more areas available for the community to enjoy.



Invasive plants grow fast and can take over important habitats. They block sunlight, crowd out native plants, and limit food and shelter for wildlife. They can also make trails hard to use or unsafe.

To make sure the biggest needs are addressed first, the City created a clear system for choosing project sites. This system looks at things like how much harm invasive plants are causing, how much work is needed to keep an area healthy, and what resources are available. Once a site is selected, staff create a multi-year plan for removing invasive plants and bringing native plants back. 



By the end of FY26, the MSA will have supported projects at 28 parks and greenway locations, improving more than 90 acres of land. These efforts have already created many benefits:



This progress is possible because Raleigh Parks has a team of trained natural resource professionals who carefully study each site and use science-based methods to guide their work. Their planning, attention to detail, and long-term approach help protect the land now and for future generations.



The program also supports young professionals through partnerships with groups like American Conservation Experience (ACE) and Conservation Corps of North Carolina (CCNC), giving them hands-on experience in conservation work. 



Many invasive species projects require continued treatment over several years. With more MSA support, Raleigh Parks will be able to maintain restored areas, expand into new locations, and protect the investments made since the program began in 2015.



Raleigh Parks remains committed to caring for the natural areas our community values, using thoughtful planning, strong partnerships, and expert guidance every step of the way.

View the Invasive Species Program Master Services Agreement (MSA) Report: FY ’25 & FY ‘26

item.title: City of Raleigh Spring Youth Athletic Registration (Jan 14, 2026)
item.description:
The City of Raleigh Athletics Department will be offering youth softball, baseball, flag football, and cheerleading for ages 5 - 17. 



Programs will be offered at various park locations throughout the city. Registration will be held from Feb. 1 - 14. Interested athletes may register online or at any City of Raleigh community center. The Athletics Program will provide all general equipment and uniforms to registered athletes, enabling them to participate in the program. To determine your child's league age, please refer to the age chart.



Locations: Varies 
Dates: Feb. 1 - Feb. 14
Ages: 5-17
Cost: $65 for Raleigh residents and $80 for non-residents
Register on RecLink starting Feb. 1



Calling all young sports stars and future MVPs! Raleigh Athletics will be hosting the 2026 Youth Athletics Spring Signing Day event on Saturday, Feb. 7, 11 a.m. - 1 p.m. at Millbrook Exchange Park and Community Center. 



This fun-filled event will officially promote the 2026 youth athletics spring registration, offering families a chance to register their children for the upcoming season and enjoy a day of excitement and community spirit. This is more than just sign-ups—it's a celebration of youth, teamwork, and the joy of sports.



Location: Millbrook Exchange
Date: Saturday, Feb. 7
Time: 11 a.m. - 1 p.m.



For general information about youth athletic offerings, please visit Raleigh Parks Youth Athletics.
For questions, contact Athletics at 919-996-6836 or email athletics@raleighnc.gov.

item.title: Winter Storm Watch (Jan 21, 2026)
item.description:
City services impacted by the weather will be listed here.



Check our Events feed to see if other specific events or meetings have been canceled or postponed. 



We are aware that the Buddhist monks will pass through Raleigh this weekend on their 2,300-mile Walk for Peace. Weather may impact their route and schedule. To stay updated on their progress, please follow their official Facebook page.



Need a warm place to stay the night? Need a meal for your family? Need shoes or a coat? 

View our list of resources.

item.title: Love Bugs (Jan 21, 2026)
item.description:
Our theme will be love, wearing red, reading about love, and making a special love bug craft. Bring a friend.



This Lovebug program will focus on fostering emotional skills (such as love and friendship) and basic science concepts (insects) through hands-on art, songs, and nature exploration. 

Children will learn to appreciate bugs and practice kindness through crafts, such as making their own colorful ‘love bugs’ from craft supplies or natural items, along with stories and simple experiments. The program creates a joyful, engaging environment for learning about feelings and the world around them.



Location: Barwell Road Park
Date: Wednesday, Feb. 11
Time: 10 - 11 a.m.
Ages: 3-5 (accompanied by an adult)
Cost: $5
Register on RecLink

item.title: Celebrate Valentine's Day with Raleigh Parks (Jan 21, 2026)
item.description:
Wednesday, Feb. 4 - Friday, Feb. 13., Various Times, Ages: 18 and up, Cost: Free
Various locations

Kids will have the chance to make handmade cards, gifts, and keepsakes for someone special. Supplies will be provided.

The Chapel at Dix Park
We’re hosting a vibrant, masquerade-style evening where adults can get glammed up and celebrate Mardi Gras in style with music, masks, and magic all night long. Attendees will dance the night away to beats from our DJ, sip on adult beverages from local vendors at our cash bar, enjoy complimentary hors d’oeuvres, and indulge in festive mocktails crafted by talented mixologists on-site.



Wednesday, Feb. 11, 10 - 11 a.m., Ages: 3 - 5, Cost: $5
Barwell Road Park
This Lovebug program will focus on fostering emotional skills (such as love and friendship) and basic science concepts (insects) through hands-on art, songs, and nature exploration. 



Friday, Feb. 13, 7 - 9 p.m., Ages: 21 and up, Cost: $25 - $39
City of Raleigh Museum
Make vintage-inspired cards, sip drinks, and try chocolates. We will provide all of the crafting supplies and the ambiance. This is a wonderful activity for couples, friends, and folks looking to build new community, all for a good cause. 100% of profits from this event go to support free educational programs at the museum.



Friday, Feb. 20, 5 - 6:30 p.m., Ages: 3 and up, Cost: Free
Kiwanis Park
Kick off the event with a charming tea time, featuring a variety of delicious teas and treats to enjoy while mingling with new friends. Get ready to socialize and engage in lively games that promote laughter and connection across generations.

item.title: Youth Spring Soccer League (Jan 13, 2026)
item.description:
This league is intended to promote interest in soccer among young athletes and teach the fundamentals and rules of the sport. All teams are coached by trained and certified volunteer coaches. 

Participants will experience playing in a team sport, with an emphasis on sportsmanship, fair play, and fostering a love for the game. League age is determined by Aug. 31, 2025. 

Practices will start in March, and the season will run through the end of May.

item.description:

item.description:

item.title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club (Jan 5, 2026)
item.description:
Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.



Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

item.title: Worthdale Walk-a-Thon (Jan 20, 2026)
item.description:
On Friday, Feb. 13, from 11 a.m. – 1 p.m. at the Worthdale Community Center, we will have our first active adult Walk-A-Thon. This fun and free event is designed to get you moving while connecting with the community. 

We’ll kick things off with line dancing to warm up, followed by our walk, and end with a relaxing cool-down session. Enjoy vendors along the way and make it a day of wellness, movement, and fellowship. 

Registration is not required but encouraged. All active adults are welcome come walk with us!

Location: Worthdale Community Center
Date: Friday, Feb. 13
Time: 11 a.m. - 1 p.m.
Ages: 50 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Introduction to Honeybees and Beekeeping (Jan 20, 2026)
item.description:
The honeybee serves an important party in pollinating flowers, especially the flowers that produce our fruits and vegetables. They also provide us honey to eat. 

Come and learn about the honeybee, beekeeping as a hobby, and increase your awareness of this important pollinator in our midst. This is a family friendly program. 

There will be a presentation, hands on stations, and a Q&A at the end. If you an interest in the honeybee or beekeeping, then this is the program for you! Please register each person who plans to attend.



Location: Laurel Hills Park
Date: Saturday, March 28
Time: 10:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.
Ages: 9 and up
Cost: $5

item.description:
Celebrate the influential women who shaped Raleigh's history and explore their stories throughout Raleigh, from the women who broke barriers in North Carolina politics to those who fought for equality during the Civil Rights Movement. 

For questions or more information, please call the Mordecai Historic Park Visitor Center at 919-996-4364

item.title: Residential Urbanity: A Modern Showcase of Triangle Skate Photographers (Jan 12, 2026)
item.description:
In partnership with Skate Raleigh and as part of Downtown Raleigh Alliance’s First Friday events for February, we’re hosting a showcase of three local skate photographers and the backstory behind some of their favorite shots from recent years.



Starting at 6 p.m., we’ll see selections from Zorah Olivia, Chris Facey, and Clinton Perry, along with Q&A, hosted by Miguel Magallanes from Endless Grind. Due to limited space, this will be a free but ticketed event. Use this form to RSVP.

Location: City of Raleigh Museum
Date: Friday, Feb. 6
Time: 6 - 9 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free
RSVP for Residential Urbanity

item.title: Pullen Park Amusements Temporarily Closed February - March (Jan 12, 2026)
item.description:
During the first phase of the project (February 2-March 31), all Pullen Park Amusements will be fully closed to ensure visitor safety and allow construction crews access around the lake. This includes all attractions, amenities, playgrounds, and picnic shelters.



Pullen Aquatic Center, Pullen Community Center, and tennis courts will remain open.



The project is expected to continue from April to August, but most areas of Pullen Amusements will reopen during that time.



Over the years, the concrete shoreline walls and railings around Lake Howell have deteriorated and begun to lose their structural stability. To protect this well-loved area, this project will include:



The only shoreline section not included in this phase is the area near the dam at the east end of the lake, which is stable.



During the week of January 12, fish will be carefully relocated to the two upper ponds in Pullen Park. Lake Howell will be restocked with fish once construction is complete.



During the week of January 19, Lake Howell will be drained to allow crews safe access to the shoreline. For visitor safety, pathways surrounding the lake will be closed during this process.



Pullen Park is one of Raleigh’s most treasured community spaces, welcoming thousands of families, walkers, and visitors each year. These upgrades will help:



We appreciate the community’s support and understanding as we make these needed improvements that will help keep Pullen Park safe, accessible, and enjoyable for years to come. We encourage you to explore other Raleigh Parks while improvements are underway. For updates, visit the Project webpage or follow Raleigh Parks on social media.

item.title: Sign Up for Volleyball Skills Training at Biltmore Hills Community Center (Jan 2, 2026)
item.description:
We will also work on the importance of sportsmanship and how to behave in a team environment. The goal of this program is to prepare our athletes to compete at the highest level all while making it affordable and creating the best experience for our participants.

item.description:

Please bring a water bottle and be prepared to spend time outside. Wear clothes that you will be comfortable hiking off-trail in. We will provide all necessary equipment.

Dates: Tuesdays & Thursdays - Jan. 15, Feb. 12, March 10, April 16

item.title: Join Us for Family and Youth Programs (Jan 12, 2026)
item.description:
Hill Street Neighborhood Center



News Published 1/12/2026 Updated 1/12/2026



Zumbini combines music, movement, and interactive activities that help children develop coordination, social skills, and self-expression, all while having a blast! Parents will love watching their kids build confidence and friendships in a safe, supportive environment.



Dates: Mondays
Time: 4:45 - 5:30 p.m. (Ages: 2-3), 5:30 - 6:15 p.m. (Ages: 4-5)
Ages: 2-3 and 4-5
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



Your little dancer will have tons of fun learning the basics of ballet and tap. The class will help them develop balance, coordination, and self-confidence. They will learn basic techniques, body positions, and steps. Everything they learn will come together in an end-of-course performance for the parents to enjoy.



Dates: Tuesdays
Times: 4:45 - 5:15 p.m. 
Ages: 2 - 3
Cost: $30
Register on RecLink



Your little dancer will have tons of fun learning the basics of ballet and tap. The class will help develop balance, coordination, and self-confidence. Students will learn basic technique, body position, and steps.



Dates: Tuesdays
Times: 5:15 - 6:15 p.m.
Ages: 4 - 5
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



Your dancer will have tons of fun learning the basics of ballet, tap, and jazz. This class will help them develop balance, coordination, and self-confidence. All while learning basic technique, body positions and steps in each style of dance. Everything they learn will come together for an end-of-session performance for the parents to enjoy.



Date: Thursdays
Time: 5:30 - 6:30 p.m.
Ages: 6 - 12 
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



This fun yoga series combines age-appropriate poses with imaginative yoga adventures, delightful books and music while offering a special time for parents and caregivers to connect with their child. Grown ups, get your silly hats on! We will hiss in cobra pose, bark in downward dog, and flutter our wings in butterfly all while building strength, coordination, and balance! Your little yogi will love this class with you and everyone will leave more centered and ready to face the weekend. Grown-ups and children should both wear clothes for movement. Please bring a yoga mat. Register child only.



Date: Saturdays
Time: 11:15 a.m. - Noon
Ages: 3 - 5
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



Hill Street Park
2307 Hill Street
Raleigh, NC 27604



919-996-5300



Hill Street Park



This feedback widget is not intended for customer service issues.



This feedback is reviewed monthly to help us improve our site. For immediate customer service please refer to our staff directory.

item.title: Greenway After Dark Series (Jan 12, 2026)
item.description:
This drop-in program is set up to allow you to get outside, enjoy the greenway, and meet your fitness goals this winter.  We will meet at designated locations, and you will be able to move down the greenway and back as you choose.  

Each week, we will have a different section of the greenway available to accommodate up to a 3-mile (5Km) run or walk.  Strollers and pets are welcome. Parks staff will be available to provide general direction and support during the program timeframe. 

Pre-registration helps us prepare, but is not required.  Get up-to-date location and weather alerts here.



Time: 5 - 8 p.m.
Ages: 16 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Zumba at Lake Lynn! (Jan 9, 2026)
item.description:
Tanessa Barlow, the instructor has taught Zumba for 18 years. She has a fun, energetic, and motivating class that allows you to dance the stress away. No prior dance experience or background necessary. Come join Zumba at Lake Lynn!

Location: Lake Lynn Community Center
Wednesdays: 6:30 - 7:30 p.m.
Saturdays:  10 - 11 a.m. 
Ages: 18 and older

item.title: Teen Trek Out! (Jan 5, 2026)
item.description:
The Teen Trek Out experience is one like no other.  Enjoy a day packed with adventure, laughs, and a good time. Join us as we venture across Raleigh for two fieldtrips and lunch because days off should never be boring. See you there!



Location: Peach Road Park
Date: Monday, Jan. 26

item.title: Call for Nominations: Fred Fletcher Outstanding Volunteer Awards (Jan 1, 2026)
item.description:
This annual event recognizes individuals and groups whose exceptional service and commitment have made a significant impact within the Raleigh Parks Department and the communities that we serve.



We invite community members, organizations, and colleagues to participate in this important recognition process. By submitting a nomination, you help ensure that the invaluable contributions of our volunteers are acknowledged and celebrated.



For More information about the award categories and the nomination process, please visit our website.

item.title: Invasive Species Awareness Day (Jan 16, 2026)
item.description:
We'll be shining a light on invasive species management throughout our beautiful city. Dive into the exciting world of conservation with experts in natural resource techniques. 

Bring your family to explore an urban wetland while enjoying a free hot chocolate bar! This event is appropriate for the naturally curious of all ages. We hope to see you there!



Location: Walnut Creek Wetland Park
Date: Saturday, Feb. 28
Time: 10 a.m. - 2 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free
No Registration is Required

item.title: Glow-in-the-Dark Centerline Paint Survey (Jan 8, 2026)
item.description:
Last year, Raleigh Parks installed a glow-in-the-dark centerline stripe on the Crabtree Creek Trail, between Kiwanis Park and Atlantic Ave, to improve visibility and enhance user safety.



Your feedback will help us understand how helpful this feature has been and whether it should be expanded to other sections of the greenway.



This brief survey will take 2 - 3 minutes to complete. Your responses are anonymous and will be used to guide future improvements to the Capital Area Greenway System. Take the Glow-in-the-Dark Centerline Paint Survey



Thank you for helping us shape the future of Raleigh’s greenways!

item.title: Savvy Sisters Golden Years Club Activities (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Established in 2024, Savvy Sisters is a social club that encourages women aged 50+ to thrive through friendships, gatherings, off-site day trips, involvement in local charity support, speakers, arts and crafts, and more! Join us and see how you can be involved in our vibrant community and help to shape our future together!



Get into the Savvy Spirit with us! Come share in our story and be part of our 2026 in the making! It's going to be a memorable day of connection, laughter and community spirit, with a fantastic ice breaker that will have you mingling and laughing with fellow attendees; there will be games, gifts, raffles, bingo sessions, delicious treats, and shots of our "savvy sisters' good times together."



The State of North Carolina Department of Agriculture presentation by our president, Alice Christiansen. She will share the seasonal benefits and perks for our senior community offered by the Department. There will be fun quizzes, agricultural gifts, snacks, and prizes. Please contact Alice for more information at 919-434-6318.



Location: Five Points Center for Active Adults
Date: Wednesday, Jan. 14
Time: 11 a.m.- 12:30 p.m
Ages: 50 and up
Cost: Free
Register at RecLink

item.title: Sprouts Soccer (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Designed for ages 3–4, our program helps children build basic soccer skills, coordination, and confidence, all while having a great time. 

Each session meets once a week for a month, giving children a consistent routine to learn and grow. Come be a part of the fun! Participants should bring water and wear sneakers. Registration is required.

Location: Peach Road Park
Date: Wednesdays from April 1 - April 22 & May 6 - May 27
Time: 3:30 - 4:15 p.m.
Ages: 3 - 4
Cost: $41 Resident / $56 Non-Resident 
Register on RecLink

item.title: Move Together Kiwanis (Jan 15, 2026)
item.description:
Each session focuses on a different age group and features activities that are engaging, age-appropriate, and exciting. All activities will take place outdoors, weather permitting.



Cost: $5 per participant 
Register on RecLink

item.title: Get Ready for the Snowball Showdown! (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
This game will be full of laughs, speedy runs, and amazing teamwork as everyone jumps in to play this safe and exciting snowy adventure. But the fun doesn’t stop there! After the showdown, everyone gets to warm up with yummy snacks, including ooey-gooey, delicious s’mores for the sweetest ending ever!  Let the snowball fun begin!

Location: Powell Drive Park
Date: Friday, Feb. 20
Time: 5:45 - 6:45 p.m. (ages 6 - 7), 7:15 - 8:15 p.m. (ages 8 -9)
Ages: 6 - 9 
Cost: $10
Register on RecLink

item.title: Join the ZigZaggers at Powell Drive Park to get Active! (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Location: Powell Drive Park
Date: Wednesdays
Time: 6 - 7 p.m. (Beginner level),  7 - 9 p.m. (Advanced Level)
Cost: $5 per month (Free in January and February)
Ages: 13 and up
Register on RecLink

item.title: Build Confidence Outdoors with Survival Skills Programs (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
From navigating the wilderness without technology to mastering practical knot-tying skills, these programs offer engaging experiences for all ages.



Learning knots has never been so fun! Kids will explore how knots are used in outdoor adventures, creative problem-solving, and everyday life. Participants will learn to tie several useful and impressive knots, practice their new skills, and finish the program by creating a paracord bracelet to wear home with pride. Adults must accompany children; accompanying adults attend free and do not need to register.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Dates and Times: Saturday, Jan. 17 (9 - 11 a.m.) and Sunday, March 8 (1 - 3 p.m.)
Ages: 7 - 12
Cost $6
Register on RecLink



Ready to unplug and try something new? Orienteering 101 offers adults the chance to step off the beaten path and into the woods of Lake Johnson Park with nothing but a map and a compass. This beginner-friendly course introduces the basics of navigation—reading a compass, taking bearings, and understanding topographic maps—so you can feel confident exploring without relying on your phone or GPS. No experience is needed, just a sense of curiosity and adventure. Advanced registration is required.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Date: Sunday, Feb. 8 and March 8 
Time: 1 - 4 p.m.
Ages: 16 and up
Cost: $12
Register on RecLink



These engaging programs are a great way to build skills, boost confidence, and create memorable outdoor experiences—whether you’re navigating the woods or tying your very first knot.



To register, visit RecLink.RaleighNC.gov or register in person at any community center.

item.title: Ready to Ride this Spring! (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Hit the trails with Mountain Bike Basics in the morning and stay for Trailside Maintenance in the afternoon.



Location: Forest Ridge Park
Dates: Saturday, March 7 and April 18
Time: 9 - 11 a.m. (Mountain Bike Basics) /  1 - 3 p.m. (Trailside Maintenance)
Cost: Varies ($12 - $41)
Ages: 14 and older
Register on RecLink

item.title: Winter Tree Identification (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
In this program, you will learn to identify local trees based on bark, limb, buds, and branching patterns as well as leaves, seed,s and habitat. Participants will receive field guides for local trees to keep and take home. This is an outdoor event, and you should dress for the weather conditions. 

Participants are eligible to receive three hours of Criteria II (outdoor) or Criteria III credit toward N.C. Environmental Educator Certification. Sign up today and answer the question, 'What kind of tree is that?'

Location: Forest Ridge Park
Date: Sunday, Feb. 1
Time: 1 - 4 p.m.
Ages: 18 and up
Cost: $10
Register on RecLink

item.title: Share Your Ideas for Biltmore Hills Park (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
News Published 1/7/2026 Updated 1/7/2026



Community members are encouraged to participate either in person or online. Public input will help inform design options and shape the long-term vision for the expansion and enhancement of Biltmore Hills Park.

An Initial Input Public Meeting will be held on Thursday, Jan. 29, from 4 to 6 p.m. at the Biltmore Hills Community Center. This family-friendly public workshop will give participants the opportunity to learn about the project, explore early design ideas, and share feedback on what improvements are most important to them.

For those unable to attend in person, an online survey will be available from Jan. 26 through Feb. 16, providing another way to share input and participate in the planning process.

Accommodation and translation services are available upon request. Please email BiltmoreHillsUpdate@publicinput.com for assistance.



More information about the project, engagement opportunities, and online participation is available on the project engagement portal.



Location: Biltmore Hills Community Center
Date: Thursday, Jan. 29
Time: 4 - 6 p.m.
Ages: All
No Registration is Required



January 29, 2026 4:00PM



BiltmoreHillsUpdate@PublicInput.com



Biltmore Hills Park



This feedback widget is not intended for customer service issues.



This feedback is reviewed monthly to help us improve our site. For immediate customer service please refer to our staff directory.

item.title: Mental Health Check-In (Jan 6, 2026)
item.description:
Globally, food is recognized as medicine, culture, and a cornerstone of community. This check-in invites us to begin approaching it in the same way, examining how our relationship with food shapes our well-being across multiple dimensions.



This experience reflects a grassroots approach to wellness—neighbors, professionals, and organizers working side by side to ensure our community has access to holistic, non-clinical support. Food and drinks will be available for purchase.

Hosted by Let’s Get Social Raleigh Foundation INC and John P. Top Green African American Cultural Center

Location: John P. "Top" Greene African American Cultural Center
Date: Monday, Feb. 2
Time: 6:30 - 9:30 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free
No Registration Required

item.title: Poetry Jam & Creative Writing Throwdown (Dec 30, 2025)
item.description:
Join fellow writers and orators in an informal and welcoming space where we are free to craft, read, and spit poetry, prose, and spoken word. Whether you're working on a masterpiece or just jotting down thoughts, let's share inspiration and creativity as we unleash the powerful beauty of words. Bring your writing, your voice, and your open ear!



Location: Five Points Center for Active Adults
Date: The third Friday of every month
Time: 3 - 5 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Introduction to Whitewater Kayaking (Dec 30, 2025)
item.description:
Our certified instructors will guide you through the basics, including how to launch your kayak, proper posture, paddle strokes, and self-rescue. Whether you are brand new to kayaking or looking to sharpen your skills, this pool-based class has you covered. All equipment is provided.

Please wear a bathing suit or other clothing that can get wet. Bring a towel, change of clothing, water bottle, and any necessary snacks. Goggles and nose clip are recommended but not required.

Location: Optimist Pool
Date: Saturday, Jan. 24
Time:  Noon - 4 p.m.
Ages: 14 and older 
Cost: $65 Residents / $80 Non-Residents
Register on RecLink

item.title: LGBTQIA+ Film Series (Dec 30, 2025)
item.description:
Join us for our monthly program on the first and fourth Tuesday of the month. We will be showcasing films with diverse themes around sexuality and gender. This program is co-hosted with the Carolina Aging Alliance.

Seating is limited, so please register in person or online. To register, visit reclink.raleighnc.gov and search keyword "LGBTQIA" or in person at any community center.



January's second film is "Weekend." After a drunken house party with his straight mates, Russell heads out to a gay club. Just before closing time, he picks up Glen but what's expected to be short lived becomes something special. This program is co-hosted with the Carolina Aging Alliance. 



Date: Tuesday, Jan. 27
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink



February's first film is "Desert Hearts". While waiting for her divorce papers, a repressed professor of literature is unexpectedly seduced by a carefree, spirited young lesbian.



Date: Tuesday, Feb. 3
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink



February's second film is "Beautiful Thing." Jamie is a shy teenager, often bullied at school. His neighbor Ste has a rough time at home, being beaten by his father and brother. This issues bring them together and they find that what they feel for each other is more than friendship.



Date: Tuesday, Feb. 17
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink
